title: In a season promising change, the 2025 Patriots looked all too familiar in season opener
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: The New England Patriots lost their season opener 20-13 to the Las Vegas Raiders at Gillette Stadium.
Quarterback Drake Maye struggled in the second half, contributing to New England's offensive issues and poor execution.
Despite defensive highlights, free-agent Harold Landry's 2.5 sacks couldn't prevent the Raiders' explosive plays and 362 passing yards.

title: Will Campbell’s NFL debut was solid until things began to unravel late in the second half
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Rookie Will Campbell struggled late in his NFL debut with the Patriots, incurring two sacks and false start penalties.
Patriots coach Mike Vrabel refrained from assessing Campbell's debut performance, stating a need to review game footage first.
Despite late-game errors, Raiders' Maxx Crosby praised Campbell's potential and future under Patriots coach Josh McDaniels.

title: Lynn police officer on leave after becoming ‘suddenly incapacitated’ while on duty
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: A Lynn police officer is on leave after becoming incapacitated during a traffic stop, allegedly due to a medical episode.
The incident was captured on video, showing the officer unresponsive, blinking slowly, and struggling to stand.
Lynn police are examining all factors in the investigation, including body camera footage and consulting medical professionals.

title: Patriots stock watch: Here’s who stood out and struggled against the Raiders
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Patriots lost 20-13 to Raiders, beginning Mike Vrabel's era with a defeat at Gillette Stadium.
Harold Landry III excelled with 2.5 sacks, marking a standout performance against Las Vegas.
New England's running backs struggled, amassing only 60 rushing yards on 18 carries during the game.

title: Review & setlist: Dropkick Murphys come on strong, avert disaster at soggy Suffolk Downs
author: Marc Hirsh
bullets: Dropkick Murphys performed at Seisiún festival in Boston after a two-hour rain delay at Suffolk Downs.
Thunderstorms forced evacuation of Suffolk Downs, delaying the performance and impacting attendance.
The band played a high-energy setlist featuring songs like 'The Boys Are Back' and 'I'm Shipping Up To Boston'.

title: Bill Belichick explains ‘simple’ reason why he decided to ban Patriots scout at UNC
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Bill Belichick banned a Patriots scout from UNC practices citing unwelcome treatment at their facility.
Belichick's strained relationship with the Patriots intensified after comments exchanged with owner Robert Kraft.
Patriots coach Mike Vrabel stated the team would find alternative ways to scout UNC players despite the ban.

title: 6 takeaways from Patriots’ 20-13 loss to Raiders
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Drake Maye completed 30 of 46 passes for 287 yards with 1 touchdown and 1 interception against the Raiders.
The Patriots' offense stalled in the second half, scoring only 3 points and ending five drives with punts.
Harold Landry excelled defensively for the Patriots, recording 2.5 sacks in his debut with the team.

title: Watch: Dropkick Murphys blast Trump, but stump for a longshot New England candidate
author: Peter Chianca
bullets: Dropkick Murphys frontman Ken Casey criticized Donald Trump during their set at Boston's Seisiún Irish music festival.
Casey endorsed Graham Platner, a Marine Corps veteran from Maine, challenging GOP Sen. Susan Collins in the 2025 election.
Platner, a millennial oyster farmer and veteran, seeks to oppose Trumpism and challenge the Democratic establishment.

title: Tenants move into first downtown apartment in Wu’s office-residential conversion program
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: First offices-to-apartments conversion at 281 Franklin St. creates 15 new units through Mayor Wu's program.
Boston Pinnacle Properties developed project with $15 million state funding and tax breaks for renovations.
Critics urge broader strategy, noting over 20% of Boston office space is vacant; Wu's program aims for 800 new units.

title: Disciplinary cases tripled at Harvard due to pro-Palestine protests, student newspaper reports
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Harvard disciplinary cases tripled in 2023-2024 due to pro-Palestine protests, per The Harvard Crimson report.
58 students were placed on probation for participating in protests, highest since 2017-2018, says the student newspaper.
A faculty committee reviewed disciplinary actions after protests over stricter enforcement of protest policies at Harvard.
